JUDGES: Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ineta Ziemele;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Kristina Pardalos;Mihai Poalelungi;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in ORG . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) are represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant and PERSON have a child who was born on CARDINAL DATE . In DATE , the couple split up and the applicant returned to live with his parents . At that time the child was cared for by the paternal grandparents . Soon after the separation , PERSON married ORG and then changed her workplace to ORG , QUANTITY away from their former residence .

CARDINAL . Relations between the applicant and PERSON deteriorated significantly after their separation . They engaged in extensive litigation concerning the division of property they had acquired during their relationship .

In addition , both parents filed for custody of the child . On DATE the applicant asked for temporary custody pending the outcome of the main proceedings . On DATE ORG granted him that right . A similar request lodged by the mother was dismissed by the same court on DATE .

CARDINAL . From DATE the applicant enrolled the child at School no . CARDINAL , at kindergarten level , where he remained until DATE when his mother enrolled him at a kindergarten in GPE , closer to her work place and that of her husband . At that time PERSON was a judge at ORG and subsequently a prosecutor in ORG attached to that district court . Her new husband was a prosecutor in the same office .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined the merits of the requests for custody lodged by the CARDINAL parents and found in favour of the mother . It granted visiting rights to the applicant . The court noted that most of the mutual allegations of lack of interest in the child and unfitness to take care of him remained unsubstantiated , the only proven fact being the extreme animosity between the parents .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed and on DATE ORG upheld the custodial decision and set a visiting schedule for the applicant , who was entitled to take the child to his home as follows : DATE , from TIME on DATE to TIME on DATE ; DATE of every school holiday ; and DATE during DATE . The child was to be picked up by the applicant from “ Kindergarten no . CARDINAL ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed on points of law , reiterating his request for custody ; he agreed to the pick - up point set by the court as “ Kindergarten no . CARDINAL ” . In a final decision of DATE ORG took note that the applicant had retracted his appeal .
CARDINAL . DATE , in accordance with the visiting schedule , the applicant went to the kindergarten where his child used to be enrolled allegedly “ CARDINAL times ” , but the mother never showed up .

CARDINAL . In DATE he initiated enforcement proceedings , without success ; the bailiff compiled several reports ( dated DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , and DATE ) confirming the mother ’s failure to comply with the provisions of the county court decision .

CARDINAL . Starting from DATE , several criminal complaints ( allegedly CARDINAL ) were lodged by the applicant against D.O for noncompliance with the provisions of the final enforceable decision . ORG attached to ORG joined the examination of the various complaints and on DATE decided not to prosecute on the ground that the alleged crimes had not occurred ; the prosecutor also noted that the applicant had had numerous opportunities to see the child , but he had failed to keep the appointments and preferred instead to lodge various complaints against the mother .
The prosecutor ’s decision was communicated to the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant objected to the prosecutor ’s decision , but on DATE ORG upheld it . The court noted that the applicant had not respected the pick - up point set by the courts : he had gone with the bailiff to the child ’s former kindergarten , School no . CARDINAL , whereas the mother had gone with the child to Kindergarten no . CARDINAL , which was located at a different address , as ordered by the final court decision . It also considered that the applicant ’s intention was to find fault with the mother and pointed out , based on the evidence adduced before it , that the applicant had only visited the child in his new kindergarten , in GPE , once , accompanied by the bailiff , and on that occasion he had tried to take the child with him by force , causing a scene which had traumatised the child .
CARDINAL . In a final decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG and Justice upheld the prosecutor ’s decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed for the clarification of the county court decision of DATE . On DATE the ORG sitting in camera granted his request and acknowledged that “ Kindergarten no . CARDINAL ” was to be understood to be “ the kindergarten belonging to School no . CARDINAL ” . The parties were not summoned to the proceedings .

CARDINAL . Several other criminal complaints lodged by the applicant against PERSON were dismissed by the prosecutor on DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE for the same reasons as those provided in the decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . The relevant domestic legal provisions are set out in the ORG ’s judgments in GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE ) , and GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , CARDINAL DATE ) . The role and responsibilities of the local public authorities in respect of social assistance and child protection , as well as the relevant provisions of LAW no . ORG are described in the judgment in GPE , ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE and DATE , CARDINAL DATE ) .
